tn.text: "If you will come back to me, people of Israel or "If you will change your behavior, people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: then it should be to me that you return
tn.text: Possible meanings are that 1) this is a repetition of the first phrase: "if you will return to me," AT: "then come back to me" or "then start worshiping me again," or 2) this is a command, "then return to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: If you remove your detestable things from before me
tn.text: This phrase refers to idols as things that deserve strong hatred. AT: "Remove your disgusting idols from my presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: do not wander from me again
tn.text: "Wander" is a metaphor for being unfaithful. AT: "remain faithful to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Plow your own ground, and do not sow among thorns
tn.text: Yahweh tells the people to prepare their lives like a farmer prepares the ground for planting. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Be circumcised to Yahweh and remove the foreskins of your heart
tn.text: Yahweh describes the people's devotion to him in terms of the physical sign of covenant. AT: "Dedicate yourselves completely to Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Be circumcised ... remove the foreskins of your heart
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "Circumcise yourselves to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: my fury will go out like fire
tn.text: Yahweh's anger is like a fire that destroys everything. AT: "the things that I do because I am angry will be like a fire." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Report in Judah and let it be heard in Jerusalem
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: let it be heard in Jerusalem
tn.text: AT: "cause the people in Jerusalem to hear it"
These words mean basically the same thing. The phrase "a great collapse" defines what the "disaster" will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This refers to enemy armies that would come from the north. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "A powerful and merciless army approaches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a set of bushes that grew closely together.
AT: "starting to march" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
fear, dread, and shock
loud and long cry of sadness and repentance for having sinned.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: the sword is striking against their life
tn.text: "our enemies are ready to slaughter us with their swords" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"Yahweh will say" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: burning wind from the plains ... wind far stronger
tn.text: A fierce and merciless enemy is coming. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The nation is compared to a special bride in an affectionate way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: It will not winnow or cleanse them
tn.text: The words "winnow" and "cleanse" both refer to taking away the bad and leaving the good. AT: "It will not take away their sins." (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: A wind ... will come at my command
tn.text: Here "command" stands for the action of God commanding the wind to come. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This expression in Hebrew is interpreted by some modern versions as "for me" or "from me."
"announce their punishment"

tn.ref: See, he is attacking like clouds, and his chariots are like a storm
tn.text: These two sentences have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See" Parallelism) AT: "The enemy army is destructive like a strong wind storm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Woe to us, for we will be devastated
tn.text: The people say this when they see the enemy army approaching. AT: The people say. 'We will certainly be destroyed.'"

tn.ref: Cleanse your heart from wickedness, Jerusalem
tn.text: God warns the people living in Jerusalem to repent. AT: "Yahweh says to the people living in Jerusalem, 'You better change how you act."
"messengers are proclaiming" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"people heard the coming disaster" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The people would recognize that those places show this warning was getting closer to them.

tn.ref: They will be like the watchmen of a cultivated field against her all around
tn.text: AT: "they will lay siege all around the city" (See: [[:en:obe:other:siege]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
AT: "crush everything you love" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: My heart! My heart! I am in anguish in my heart. My heart is turbulent within me.
tn.text: "I am in such pain, I am overwhelmed."
full of confusion, violence, or disorder; not stable or steady
"people tell of one city after another being destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the enemy devastates the land"

The words "tabernacle" and "tent" share similar meanings. Possible meanings are "my tent and the curtains inside my tent" or "the place where I live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: How long will I see the standard? Will I hear the sound of the horn?
tn.text: These two sentences have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. AT: "I wish this war would end soon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"stupid people"

tn.ref: I saw the land, and see!
tn.text: This is an invitation for Jeremiah to look at the vision God is giving him.
This vision is a prophecy of what the land of Israel would be like after the people were all taken into captivity.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: land will mourn, and the heavens above will darken
tn.text: Jeremiah emphasizes Yahweh's judgment by saying that the earth itself expresses great sorrow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
a group of soldiers riding horses

tn.ref: Every city will flee ... Every city will climb up
tn.text: This emphasizes that all of the people will be running away.

tn.ref: The cities will be abandoned, for there will be no one to inhabit them
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. AT: "There will be no one left in the cities." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you dress in scarlet ... jewelry ... eyes ... with paint
tn.text: "you dress like prostitutes"
"decorate" or "add extras to make something appear more attractive or expensive"

tn.ref: men who lusted for you now reject you
tn.text: This emphasizes that other nations Israel has depended on for wealth and business will reject them when they see God's judgment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"distress as in the pain and suffering a woman has while giving birth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"my life is worn out from grief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
